concepts.concept_name: Biodiversity: definition, types, and patterns of diversity
Taxonomy: need, history, and taxonomic categories (species to kingdom)
Nomenclature: binomial nomenclature, ICBN and ICZN rules
Taxonomic aids: herbarium, botanical gardens, museums, zoological parks, keys

in_scope: What is living: defining characteristics — growth, reproduction, metabolism, cellular organisation, consciousness
Biodiversity: definition, number of species known, patterns of diversity
Need for classification of organisms
Taxonomy: definition, history (Linnaeus, Aristotle)
Taxonomic categories (hierarchy): species, genus, family, order, class, phylum/division, kingdom
Binomial nomenclature: rules, conventions, examples
International codes: ICBN (plants), ICZN (animals)
Concept of species and taxonomic hierarchy with examples
Taxonomic aids: herbarium, botanical gardens, museums, zoological parks
Identification keys: single-access and multi-access keys
Flora, manuals, monographs, catalogues
out_of_scope: Basic grouping of plants and animals — Covered in Classes 6-8
Detailed phylogenetics and cladistics — Class 12 / Undergraduate
Molecular taxonomy and DNA barcoding — Undergraduate
Detailed history of all taxonomists beyond Linnaeus and Aristotle

concepts.concept_name: Five-kingdom classification: Monera, Protista, Fungi, Plantae, Animalia
Kingdom Monera: Archaebacteria, Eubacteria, structure and reproduction
Kingdoms Protista and Fungi: characteristics, classification, and examples
Viruses, viroids, prions, and lichens

in_scope: History of classification: two-kingdom to five-kingdom (Whittaker 1969)
Basis of classification: cell structure, body organisation, mode of nutrition, reproduction, phylogenetic relationships
Kingdom Monera: general characters, Archaebacteria (methanogens, halophiles, thermoacidophiles), Eubacteria
Bacterial shapes: coccus, bacillus, vibrio, spirillum
Bacterial reproduction: binary fission, spore formation
Cyanobacteria (blue-green algae): photosynthetic, nitrogen fixing
Mycoplasma: smallest living cells, pathogenic
Kingdom Protista: chrysophytes (diatoms, golden algae), dinoflagellates, euglenoids, slime moulds, protozoans
Kingdom Fungi: general characters, classification — Phycomycetes, Ascomycetes, Basidiomycetes, Deuteromycetes
Fungal reproduction: vegetative, asexual (spores), sexual
Kingdom Plantae and Kingdom Animalia — salient features (detailed in later chapters)
Viruses: discovery (Ivanowsky, Beijerinck), structure (DNA/RNA, capsid), diseases, TMV, bacteriophage
Viroids: RNA particles causing plant diseases
Prions: infectious proteins
Lichens: symbiotic association of algae and fungi, significance as pollution indicators
out_of_scope: Basic classification into plants and animals — Covered in Classes 6-7
Three-domain classification (Woese) in detail — Undergraduate
Detailed virology (viral replication cycles, retroviruses) — Undergraduate
Detailed fungal biochemistry and secondary metabolites — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Algae: classification (Chlorophyceae, Phaeophyceae, Rhodophyceae), structure, reproduction
Bryophytes and Pteridophytes: characteristics, classification, life cycles
Gymnosperms and Angiosperms: characteristics, classification, life cycles
Plant life cycles: alternation of generations (haplontic, diplontic, haplo-diplontic)

in_scope: Basis of classification of plants: presence of embryo, vascular tissue, seed, flower
Algae: general characters, habitat, thallus organisation
Chlorophyceae (green algae): Chlamydomonas, Volvox, Ulothrix, Spirogyra, Chara
Phaeophyceae (brown algae): Ectocarpus, Dictyota, Laminaria, Sargassum, Fucus
Rhodophyceae (red algae): Polysiphonia, Porphyra, Gracilaria
Economic importance of algae
Bryophytes: liverworts (Marchantia), mosses (Funaria, Sphagnum), general characters
Bryophytes as amphibians of plant kingdom
Pteridophytes: general characters, classification (Psilopsida, Lycopsida, Sphenopsida, Pteropsida)
Examples: Selaginella, Equisetum, ferns (Dryopteris, Pteris, Adiantum)
Heterospory and seed habit in pteridophytes
Gymnosperms: general characters, examples (Cycas, Pinus, Ginkgo, Gnetum)
Angiosperms: general characters, dicots vs monocots, examples
Alternation of generations in plants
Life cycle patterns: haplontic, diplontic, haplo-diplontic with examples
out_of_scope: Basic plant groups — Covered in Classes 6-9
Detailed phycology (algal biochemistry, pigment analysis) — Undergraduate
Detailed bryophyte and pteridophyte anatomy — Undergraduate
Fossil gymnosperms and detailed paleobotany — Undergraduate
Detailed angiosperm systematics (APG classification) — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Basis of classification: levels of organisation, symmetry, coelom, segmentation
Non-chordates: Porifera to Echinodermata — characters and examples
Phylum Chordata: characteristics, classification (Urochordata, Cephalochordata, Vertebrata)
Vertebrate classes: Cyclostomata, Chondrichthyes, Osteichthyes, Amphibia, Reptilia, Aves, Mammalia

in_scope: Basis of classification: levels of organisation (cellular, tissue, organ, organ system)
Body symmetry: asymmetry, radial symmetry, bilateral symmetry
Diploblastic and triploblastic organisation
Coelom: acoelomate, pseudocoelomate, coelomate (with examples)
Segmentation and its significance
Notochord: definition, significance in classification
Phylum Porifera: characteristics, canal system, examples (Sycon, Euspongia, Spongilla)
Phylum Coelenterata (Cnidaria): characteristics, examples (Hydra, Obelia, Aurelia, corals)
Phylum Ctenophora: comb plates, bioluminescence, examples (Pleurobrachia, Ctenoplana)
Phylum Platyhelminthes: flatworms, flame cells, examples (Taenia, Fasciola, Planaria)
Phylum Aschelminthes (Nematoda): roundworms, examples (Ascaris, Wuchereria, Ancylostoma)
Phylum Annelida: segmentation, examples (Nereis, Pheretima, Hirudinaria)
Phylum Arthropoda: largest phylum, exoskeleton, examples (Apis, Bombyx, Limulus, Locusta, Anopheles)
Phylum Mollusca: mantle, examples (Pila, Octopus, Loligo, Unio, Sepia)
Phylum Echinodermata: water vascular system, examples (Asterias, Echinus, Antedon, Cucumaria)
Phylum Hemichordata: worm-like marine animals, examples (Balanoglossus, Saccoglossus)
Phylum Chordata: notochord, dorsal nerve cord, pharyngeal gill slits, post-anal tail
Subphylum Urochordata and Cephalochordata (protochordates): examples
Subphylum Vertebrata: division into classes
Class Cyclostomata: jawless, examples (Petromyzon, Myxine)
Class Chondrichthyes: cartilaginous fish, examples (Scoliodon, Pristis, Trygon)
Class Osteichthyes: bony fish, examples (Labeo, Catla, Exocoetus, Hippocampus)
Class Amphibia: dual life, examples (Bufo, Rana, Hyla, Salamandra, Ichthyophis)
Class Reptilia: crawling, examples (Chelone, Testudo, Chameleon, Calotes, Crocodilus, Hemidactylus)
Class Aves: feathers, flight, examples (Corvus, Columba, Psittacula, Struthio, Pavo)
Class Mammalia: mammary glands, examples (Macropus, Pteropus, Camelus, Macaca, Rattus, Canis, Felis, Elephas, Equus, Delphinus, Balaenoptera, Panthera)
out_of_scope: Basic animal classification — Covered in Classes 7-9
Detailed invertebrate zoology (organ systems of individual phyla) — Undergraduate
Detailed comparative anatomy of vertebrate organ systems — Undergraduate
Evolutionary relationships between phyla (detailed phylogeny) — Undergraduate

themes.theme_name: Structural Organisation in Animals and Plants

concepts.concept_name: Root, stem, and leaf: morphology, types, and modifications
Flower: parts, types of inflorescence, placentation
Fruit and seed: types, structure, and dispersal
Description of families: Fabaceae, Solanaceae, Liliaceae

in_scope: Root: regions, types (tap root, adventitious root), modifications (storage, pneumatophores, stilt roots)
Stem: characteristics, types, modifications (stolon, runner, sucker, tuber, bulb, corm, rhizome, thorns, tendrils, phylloclades)
Leaf: parts (petiole, lamina, stipule), venation (reticulate, parallel), types (simple, compound — pinnate, palmate)
Leaf modifications: tendrils, spines, phyllode, pitcher
Phyllotaxy: alternate, opposite, whorled
Inflorescence: racemose (raceme, spike, catkin, spadix, corymb, umbel, capitulum) and cymose (monochasial, dichasial, polychasial)
Flower: parts — calyx, corolla, androecium, gynoecium
Aestivation: valvate, twisted, imbricate, vexillary
Placentation: marginal, axile, parietal, basal, free central, superficial
Fruit: types — simple (drupe, berry, pome), aggregate, composite (sorosis, syconus)
Seed structure: monocot and dicot seed
Semi-technical description of families: Fabaceae (Papilionaceae), Solanaceae, Liliaceae
Floral formula and floral diagram
out_of_scope: Basic parts of plants — Covered in Classes 6-7
Detailed plant taxonomy (keys for identification) — Undergraduate
Families beyond Fabaceae, Solanaceae, and Liliaceae — Undergraduate
Economic botany in detail — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Plant tissues: meristematic and permanent tissues (simple and complex)
Tissue systems: epidermal, ground, and vascular tissue systems
Anatomy of dicot and monocot root, stem, and leaf
Secondary growth in dicot stem and root

in_scope: Meristematic tissues: apical, lateral, intercalary — characteristics and functions
Simple permanent tissues: parenchyma, collenchyma, sclerenchyma — structure and function
Complex permanent tissues: xylem (tracheids, vessels, xylem parenchyma, xylem fibres), phloem (sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem parenchyma, phloem fibres)
Epidermal tissue system: epidermis, stomata, trichomes, root hairs
Ground tissue system: cortex, endodermis (Casparian strip), pericycle, pith, medullary rays
Vascular tissue system: vascular bundles — open, closed, radial, conjoint (collateral, bicollateral)
Dicot root anatomy: T.S. showing epidermis, cortex, endodermis, pericycle, vascular bundles
Monocot root anatomy: comparison with dicot root
Dicot stem anatomy: T.S. showing epidermis, cortex, endodermis, pericycle, vascular bundles in ring, pith
Monocot stem anatomy: scattered vascular bundles, absence of secondary growth
Dicot leaf (dorsiventral): T.S. showing upper and lower epidermis, palisade and spongy mesophyll
Monocot leaf (isobilateral): T.S. showing bulliform cells, mesophyll without differentiation
Secondary growth: vascular cambium, cork cambium (phellogen), secondary xylem, secondary phloem
Heartwood and sapwood
Annual rings and dendrochronology (introduction)
out_of_scope: Basic plant structure — Covered in Classes 6-9
Detailed wood anatomy and timber technology — Undergraduate
Anomalous secondary growth — Undergraduate
Detailed histochemistry of plant tissues — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Animal tissues: epithelial, connective, muscular, neural tissues
Morphology and anatomy of Earthworm (Pheretima)
Morphology and anatomy of Cockroach (Periplaneta)
Morphology and anatomy of Frog (Rana)

in_scope: Epithelial tissue: types (simple — squamous, cuboidal, columnar, ciliated; compound), glandular epithelium
Connective tissue: loose (areolar, adipose), dense (regular, irregular), specialised (cartilage, bone, blood)
Muscular tissue: striated (skeletal), non-striated (smooth), cardiac — structure and function
Neural tissue: neuron structure (cell body, dendrites, axon), types of neurons (sensory, motor, interneuron)
Earthworm (Pheretima posthuma): habitat, external morphology, body wall, locomotion
Earthworm: digestive, circulatory, respiratory, excretory, nervous, reproductive systems
Cockroach (Periplaneta americana): habitat, external morphology, body regions (head, thorax, abdomen)
Cockroach: digestive, circulatory (open), respiratory (tracheal), excretory (Malpighian tubules), nervous, reproductive systems
Frog (Rana tigrina): habitat, external morphology, skin (moist, glandular)
Frog: digestive, circulatory (three-chambered heart), respiratory (cutaneous, pulmonary, buccopharyngeal), excretory, nervous, reproductive systems
Organ and organ-system level of organisation
out_of_scope: Basic animal tissues overview — Covered in Class 9
Detailed histology with advanced staining techniques — Undergraduate
Dissection procedures — Practical component only
Detailed comparative anatomy beyond the three organisms listed — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Cell theory, cell types: prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
Cell membrane: structure (fluid mosaic model) and transport
Cell organelles: nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplast, ER, Golgi, lysosomes, ribosomes
Cytoskeleton, cilia, flagella, centrioles, and microbodies

in_scope: Cell theory: Schleiden and Schwann, modification by Virchow
Overview of cell: cell as basic unit of life
Prokaryotic cell: cell envelope (glycocalyx, cell wall, cell membrane), ribosomes (70S), inclusion bodies, nucleoid, plasmid
Eukaryotic cell: plant cell vs animal cell — differences
Cell membrane: fluid mosaic model (Singer and Nicolson), structure, selective permeability
Cell wall: composition in plants (cellulose), middle lamella, plasmodesmata
Endomembrane system: endoplasmic reticulum (smooth and rough), Golgi apparatus (cisternae), lysosomes, vacuoles
Mitochondria: double membrane, cristae, matrix, own DNA, semi-autonomous
Plastids: chloroplast (thylakoids, grana, stroma, own DNA), chromoplasts, leucoplasts
Ribosomes: 70S and 80S, structure and function
Cytoskeleton: microfilaments, microtubules, intermediate filaments
Cilia and flagella: structure (9+2 arrangement), function
Centrosome and centrioles: structure and role in cell division
Nucleus: nuclear envelope, nucleoplasm, chromatin, nucleolus
Microbodies: peroxisomes
out_of_scope: Basic cell structure — Covered in Classes 8-9
Detailed membrane biochemistry (lipid rafts, signal transduction) — Undergraduate
Detailed molecular biology of organelles — Undergraduate
Electron microscopy techniques in detail — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Carbohydrates, lipids, and amino acids: structure and classification
Proteins: structure (primary to quaternary), nucleic acids (DNA, RNA)
Enzymes: properties, classification, mechanism of action, factors affecting activity

in_scope: Chemical analysis of living tissues: elemental composition, types of biomolecules
Primary metabolites vs secondary metabolites
Carbohydrates: monosaccharides (glucose, fructose, galactose), disaccharides (sucrose, lactose, maltose), polysaccharides (starch, glycogen, cellulose, chitin, inulin)
Reducing and non-reducing sugars
Lipids: simple (fats, oils), compound (phospholipids), derived (steroids, terpenes, carotenoids), saturated and unsaturated fatty acids
Amino acids: general structure, 20 standard amino acids, essential vs non-essential
Peptide bond: formation and structure
Proteins: structural levels — primary (sequence), secondary (alpha-helix, beta-sheet), tertiary (3D folding), quaternary (subunit assembly)
Nucleic acids: DNA and RNA — nucleotide structure (sugar, base, phosphate), types of RNA (mRNA, tRNA, rRNA)
Enzymes: nature (mostly proteins, some RNA — ribozymes), properties (specificity, reusability)
Enzyme nomenclature and classification (oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases, ligases)
Mechanism of enzyme action: lock and key model, induced fit model, active site
Factors affecting enzyme activity: temperature, pH, substrate concentration, enzyme concentration, inhibitors (competitive, non-competitive)
Cofactors, coenzymes, prosthetic groups, metal ions
out_of_scope: Basic biomolecules introduction — Covered in Class 9
Detailed enzyme kinetics (Michaelis-Menten equation, Lineweaver-Burk plots) — Undergraduate
Detailed protein crystallography and structural biology — Undergraduate
Metabolic pathways of secondary metabolites — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Cell cycle: phases (G1, S, G2, M) and regulation
Mitosis: stages (prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase), cytokinesis, significance
Meiosis: stages (meiosis I and II), crossing over, significance

in_scope: Cell cycle: definition, phases — interphase (G1, S, G2) and M phase (mitosis + cytokinesis)
Quiescent stage (G0 phase)
Duration of cell cycle in different cell types
Mitosis: definition, occurrence, stages
Prophase: chromatin condensation, centriole migration, spindle formation, nuclear envelope breakdown
Metaphase: chromosomes at metaphase plate, spindle attachment at kinetochore
Anaphase: centromere splitting, chromatid separation, movement to poles
Telophase: nuclear envelope reformation, chromatin decondensation, nucleolus reappearance
Cytokinesis: cell plate formation (plants) vs cleavage furrow (animals)
Significance of mitosis: growth, repair, asexual reproduction, genetic consistency
Meiosis: definition, occurrence, significance
Meiosis I: prophase I (leptotene, zygotene, pachytene, diplotene, diakinesis), metaphase I, anaphase I, telophase I
Crossing over: mechanism and significance in genetic variation
Meiosis II: similar to mitosis, separation of sister chromatids
Significance of meiosis: reduction in chromosome number, genetic variation, gamete formation
Comparison of mitosis and meiosis
out_of_scope: Basic cell division introduction — Covered in Class 9-10
Detailed cell cycle regulation (cyclins, CDKs, checkpoints) — Undergraduate
Cancer biology and cell cycle deregulation in detail — Class 12 / Undergraduate
Detailed molecular mechanisms of spindle assembly — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Light reactions: photosystems, electron transport, photophosphorylation
Calvin cycle (C3 pathway): carbon fixation, reduction, regeneration
C4 pathway, CAM plants, and photorespiration
Factors affecting photosynthesis: Blackman's law of limiting factors

in_scope: Early experiments: Priestley, Ingenhousz, Julius von Sachs, T.W. Engelmann, Cornelius van Niel
Site of photosynthesis: chloroplast structure, photosynthetic pigments (chlorophyll a, b, carotenoids, xanthophylls)
Absorption spectrum and action spectrum
Light reactions (thylakoid reactions): photosystem I (P700) and photosystem II (P680)
Non-cyclic photophosphorylation: Z-scheme, water splitting (Hill reaction), NADPH and ATP formation
Cyclic photophosphorylation: only ATP production
Chemiosmotic hypothesis: proton gradient across thylakoid membrane, ATP synthase
Calvin cycle (dark reactions / C3 pathway): carbon fixation (RuBisCO), reduction, regeneration of RuBP
Inputs and outputs of Calvin cycle: 6 turns for 1 glucose
C4 pathway (Hatch-Slack pathway): Kranz anatomy, PEP carboxylase, bundle sheath cells
C4 plants: examples (sugarcane, maize, sorghum)
CAM (Crassulacean Acid Metabolism): stomata opening at night, examples (succulents)
Photorespiration: process, wasteful nature, RuBisCO's oxygenase activity
Why C4 plants are more efficient than C3 plants
Factors affecting photosynthesis: light intensity, CO2 concentration, temperature, water
Blackman's law of limiting factors
out_of_scope: Basic photosynthesis equation and overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed biophysics of photosystems (antenna complex, reaction centre chemistry) — Undergraduate
Detailed regulation of Calvin cycle enzymes — Undergraduate
Isotope tracer experiments in detail — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Glycolysis and fermentation: steps, products, anaerobic respiration
TCA cycle (Krebs cycle) and electron transport chain: steps, ATP yield
Respiratory quotient and amphibolic nature of respiration

in_scope: Cellular respiration: definition, distinction from breathing
Do plants breathe? Gas exchange in plants through stomata, lenticels
Glycolysis: location (cytoplasm), steps overview, net products (2 pyruvate, 2 ATP, 2 NADH)
Fate of pyruvate: aerobic (TCA cycle) vs anaerobic (fermentation)
Fermentation: alcoholic fermentation (yeast), lactic acid fermentation (muscle cells)
Oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate: pyruvate to acetyl CoA (link reaction)
TCA cycle (Krebs cycle): location (mitochondrial matrix), steps overview, products per turn (3 NADH, 1 FADH2, 1 GTP, 2 CO2)
Electron transport chain (ETC): location (inner mitochondrial membrane), complexes I-IV, role of oxygen as terminal electron acceptor
Oxidative phosphorylation: chemiosmotic theory, ATP synthase, proton gradient
ATP yield: theoretical maximum from one glucose molecule (36-38 ATP)
Respiratory quotient (RQ): definition, calculation, values for carbohydrates (1), fats (<1), proteins (~0.8), organic acids (>1)
Amphibolic nature of respiration: respiratory pathway as both catabolic and anabolic
Respiratory balance sheet
out_of_scope: Basic respiration overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed enzyme mechanisms of each glycolysis step — Undergraduate
Detailed mitochondrial genetics and biogenesis — Undergraduate
Detailed regulation of respiratory pathways — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Plant growth: phases, measurement, growth rate, conditions
Plant growth regulators: auxins, gibberellins, cytokinins, ethylene, ABA
Photoperiodism, vernalisation, and seed dormancy

in_scope: Growth: definition, characteristics — irreversible increase in size, mass
Phases of growth: meristematic, elongation, maturation
Growth rate: arithmetic and geometric growth, sigmoid growth curve
Conditions for growth: water, oxygen, nutrients, temperature
Differentiation, dedifferentiation, and redifferentiation
Development: sum of growth and differentiation
Plant growth regulators (PGRs): definition, discovery
Auxins: discovery (Went's experiment), natural (IAA) and synthetic (2,4-D, NAA), effects (cell elongation, apical dominance, root initiation)
Gibberellins: discovery (Kurosawa, foolish seedling disease), effects (stem elongation, bolting, seed germination, fruit development)
Cytokinins: discovery (Skoog and Miller), effects (cell division, delay of senescence, breaking dormancy)
Ethylene: gaseous hormone, effects (fruit ripening, senescence, abscission, triple response)
Abscisic acid (ABA): stress hormone, effects (stomatal closure, seed dormancy, inhibition of growth)
Photoperiodism: short-day plants, long-day plants, day-neutral plants, critical day length, role of phytochrome
Vernalisation: cold treatment for flowering, examples (wheat, barley)
Seed dormancy: causes and methods to break dormancy
out_of_scope: Basic plant growth concepts — Covered in Classes 6-7
Detailed signal transduction pathways of PGRs — Undergraduate
Molecular biology of phytochrome and cryptochrome — Undergraduate
Detailed PGR biosynthesis pathways — Undergraduate
Tissue culture and plant biotechnology — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Water potential, osmosis, plasmolysis, imbibition, and diffusion
Absorption and movement of water: apoplast, symplast, transpiration pull
Transpiration: types, mechanism, factors, significance
Translocation of solutes: phloem transport, pressure flow hypothesis

in_scope: Means of transport: diffusion, facilitated diffusion, active transport
Plant-water relations: water potential, solute potential, pressure potential
Water potential equation: Psi_w = Psi_s + Psi_p
Osmosis: definition, types (endosmosis, exosmosis), osmotic pressure
Plasmolysis and deplasmolysis
Imbibition: definition, significance in seed germination
Long-distance transport of water: role of xylem
Absorption of water by roots: osmotic and non-osmotic
Pathway of water movement: apoplast pathway, symplast pathway, transmembrane pathway
Root pressure: guttation as evidence
Transpiration: definition, types (stomatal, cuticular, lenticular)
Mechanism of stomatal opening and closing: role of K+ ions, guard cells
Transpiration pull (cohesion-tension theory): Dixon and Joly
Factors affecting transpiration: temperature, humidity, wind speed, light, number of stomata
Transpiration: significance and consequences (necessary evil)
Translocation: phloem transport, source and sink
Pressure flow hypothesis (Munch hypothesis) for phloem transport
Uptake and transport of mineral ions: active and passive absorption
out_of_scope: Basic transport in plants — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed aquaporin biology — Undergraduate
Detailed ion channel physiology — Undergraduate
Mathematical modelling of water potential — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Essential mineral elements: criteria, classification (macro and micronutrients), roles
Deficiency symptoms and toxicity of mineral elements
Nitrogen metabolism: nitrogen cycle, biological nitrogen fixation

in_scope: Methods to study mineral requirements: hydroponics, solution culture techniques
Essential elements: criteria of essentiality (Arnon and Stout)
Macronutrients: N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S — roles and deficiency symptoms
Micronutrients: Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn, B, Mo, Cl, Ni — roles and deficiency symptoms
Deficiency symptoms: chlorosis, necrosis, stunted growth, delayed flowering
Critical concentration and toxicity of mineral elements
Mineral toxicity: manganese toxicity, aluminium toxicity
Mechanism of absorption: passive and active uptake of minerals
Translocation of solutes in phloem
Nitrogen cycle: nitrogen fixation, nitrification, denitrification, ammonification
Biological nitrogen fixation: symbiotic (Rhizobium in legume root nodules), free-living (Azotobacter, Anabaena, Nostoc)
Nitrogenase enzyme: structure and mechanism (anaerobic conditions, leg-haemoglobin)
Fate of ammonia: reductive amination, transamination, amide formation (asparagine, glutamine)
out_of_scope: Basic soil nutrients and manures — Covered in Classes 7-9
Detailed soil science and pedology — Undergraduate
Detailed enzymology of nitrogenase — Undergraduate
Detailed molecular biology of nitrogen fixation (nif genes) — Undergraduate
Agricultural fertilizer technology — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Alimentary canal: structure and function of each organ
Digestive glands and enzymes: salivary, gastric, pancreatic, intestinal secretions
Digestion, absorption, and assimilation of nutrients
Disorders of the digestive system: PEM, indigestion, constipation, vomiting, jaundice, diarrhoea

in_scope: Human alimentary canal: mouth, pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine (duodenum, jejunum, ileum), large intestine (caecum, colon, rectum), anus
Histology of gut wall: serosa, muscularis, submucosa, mucosa
Teeth: types (incisors, canines, premolars, molars), dental formula
Tongue: taste buds, role in mastication and swallowing
Salivary glands: parotid, sublingual, submandibular; saliva composition (salivary amylase, lysozyme, mucus)
Swallowing and peristalsis
Stomach: regions (cardiac, fundic, pyloric), gastric glands, HCl, pepsinogen, mucus, rennin (in infants)
Pancreas: exocrine function — pancreatic juice (trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, procarboxypeptidase, amylase, lipase, nucleases)
Liver: bile production (bile salts, bile pigments), role in fat emulsification, hepatic portal system
Small intestine: intestinal juice (succus entericus), brush border enzymes, absorption (villi, microvilli)
Absorption: mechanisms (active transport, passive transport, facilitated diffusion)
Absorption of glucose, amino acids, fatty acids, glycerol, vitamins, minerals, water
Assimilation: role of liver in metabolism
Egestion: formation and elimination of faeces
Disorders: protein-energy malnutrition (PEM — kwashiorkor, marasmus), indigestion, constipation, vomiting, jaundice, diarrhoea
out_of_scope: Basic digestive system overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed gastrointestinal hormones and neural regulation — Undergraduate
Clinical gastroenterology and surgery — Undergraduate / Medical
Detailed hepatic metabolism and liver function tests — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Respiratory organs and mechanism of breathing
Exchange and transport of gases: O2 and CO2
Regulation of respiration and respiratory disorders

in_scope: Human respiratory system: nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveoli
Lungs: structure, pleural membranes, pleural fluid
Mechanism of breathing: inspiration and expiration, role of diaphragm and intercostal muscles
Pulmonary volumes: tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), expiratory reserve volume (ERV), residual volume (RV)
Pulmonary capacities: inspiratory capacity (IC), vital capacity (VC), total lung capacity (TLC), functional residual capacity (FRC)
Exchange of gases: partial pressures, Dalton's law, diffusion across alveolar membrane
Transport of O2: dissolved in plasma, bound to haemoglobin (oxyhaemoglobin), oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve
Factors affecting O2-Hb dissociation: pCO2, H+ concentration, temperature (Bohr effect)
Transport of CO2: dissolved in plasma (7%), as bicarbonate ions (70%), as carbaminohaemoglobin (23%)
Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon)
Regulation of respiration: respiratory centre (medulla oblongata, pons), chemoreceptors (aortic, carotid bodies)
Role of CO2 and H+ in regulating respiration
Disorders: asthma, emphysema, occupational respiratory disorders (silicosis, asbestosis)
out_of_scope: Basic respiratory system overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed respiratory physiology (ventilation-perfusion ratio) — Undergraduate
Detailed pulmonary function testing — Undergraduate / Medical
High altitude physiology and deep-sea diving physiology — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Blood: composition, formed elements, blood groups, coagulation
Heart: structure, cardiac cycle, cardiac output, ECG
Blood vessels, double circulation, lymphatic system, and cardiovascular disorders

in_scope: Body fluids: blood, lymph (tissue fluid), interstitial fluid
Blood: plasma (water, proteins — albumin, globulin, fibrinogen), formed elements
Erythrocytes (RBCs): structure, haemoglobin, count, lifespan, formation (erythropoiesis)
Leucocytes (WBCs): types — granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils), agranulocytes (lymphocytes, monocytes), differential count
Thrombocytes (platelets): role in clotting
Blood clotting: mechanism (thromboplastin, prothrombin, thrombin, fibrinogen, fibrin), calcium ions
Blood groups: ABO system (antigens, antibodies, universal donor, universal recipient), Rh factor (erythroblastosis foetalis)
Lymph: formation, composition, functions
Human heart: external structure, internal chambers, valves (tricuspid, bicuspid, semilunar)
Cardiac cycle: atrial systole, ventricular systole, joint diastole, duration, cardiac output, stroke volume
Heart sounds: lub (AV valve closure), dub (semilunar valve closure)
Electrocardiograph (ECG): P wave, QRS complex, T wave — significance
Double circulation: pulmonary and systemic circulation
Blood vessels: arteries, veins, capillaries — structure and function
Regulation of cardiac activity: SA node (pacemaker), AV node, bundle of His, Purkinje fibres, autonomic nervous system
Disorders: hypertension, coronary artery disease, angina, heart failure, atherosclerosis
out_of_scope: Basic circulatory system overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed cardiac electrophysiology and arrhythmias — Undergraduate / Medical
Detailed haematology (blood cell disorders) — Undergraduate / Medical
Detailed haemodynamics and Starling's law — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Human excretory system: kidney structure, nephron types and structure
Urine formation: glomerular filtration, tubular reabsorption, secretion
Regulation of kidney function: hormonal control, counter-current mechanism
Disorders: uraemia, renal failure, kidney stones; dialysis and transplant

in_scope: Modes of excretion: ammonotelism, ureotelism, uricotelism — with examples
Human excretory system: kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, urethra
Kidney: external structure (bean-shaped, hilum, renal artery, renal vein)
Kidney: internal structure — cortex, medulla (pyramids), pelvis, calyces
Nephron: structure — glomerulus (Bowman's capsule), PCT, loop of Henle, DCT, collecting duct
Types of nephrons: cortical nephrons, juxtamedullary nephrons
Urine formation: ultrafiltration (GFR ~ 125 mL/min), selective reabsorption, tubular secretion
Counter-current mechanism: loop of Henle and vasa recta, concentration of urine, medullary gradient
Regulation of kidney function: ADH (antidiuretic hormone), aldosterone, ANF (atrial natriuretic factor), renin-angiotensin mechanism
Role of kidney in osmoregulation
Other excretory organs: lungs (CO2), liver (bilirubin, urea), skin (sweat)
Disorders: uraemia, renal failure (acute and chronic), renal calculi (kidney stones), glomerulonephritis
Haemodialysis: principle and procedure
Kidney transplantation
out_of_scope: Basic excretory system overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed renal physiology (clearance studies, GFR measurement techniques) — Undergraduate
Detailed acid-base balance regulation — Undergraduate
Detailed transplant immunology — Undergraduate / Medical

concepts.concept_name: Types of movement and muscle types: skeletal, smooth, cardiac muscle structure
Mechanism of muscle contraction: sliding filament theory
Skeletal system: axial and appendicular skeleton, types of joints
Disorders of muscular and skeletal system

in_scope: Types of movement: amoeboid, ciliary, muscular
Skeletal muscle: structure — muscle fibre, myofibril, sarcomere (A band, I band, H zone, Z line, M line)
Contractile proteins: actin (thin filament), myosin (thick filament), tropomyosin, troponin
Mechanism of muscle contraction: sliding filament theory (Huxley and Hanson)
Role of calcium ions, ATP, and neuromuscular junction in contraction
Muscle fibre types: red (slow twitch) and white (fast twitch)
Smooth muscle and cardiac muscle: structure and properties
Human skeletal system: 206 bones
Axial skeleton: skull (cranial and facial bones), vertebral column (cervical, thoracic, lumbar, sacral, coccygeal), ribs, sternum
Appendicular skeleton: pectoral girdle, pelvic girdle, upper limb bones, lower limb bones
Types of joints: fibrous (immovable), cartilaginous (slightly movable), synovial (freely movable — ball-and-socket, hinge, pivot, gliding, saddle, condyloid)
Disorders: myasthenia gravis, muscular dystrophy, tetany, arthritis, osteoporosis, gout
out_of_scope: Basic skeletal and muscular system — Covered in Classes 6-9
Detailed biomechanics and kinesiology — Undergraduate
Detailed neuromuscular physiology (motor unit, EMG) — Undergraduate
Detailed orthopaedics and sports medicine — Undergraduate / Medical

concepts.concept_name: Neuron: structure, types, generation and conduction of nerve impulse
Central nervous system: brain (parts and functions), spinal cord
Peripheral nervous system, reflex arc, and sense organs (eye, ear)

in_scope: Neural system: definition, components, types of neural systems in animals
Neuron: structure (cell body, dendrites, axon, axon terminal, myelin sheath, nodes of Ranvier, Schwann cells)
Types of neurons: sensory (afferent), motor (efferent), interneurons (association neurons)
Generation of nerve impulse: resting potential, action potential, depolarisation, repolarisation
Nerve impulse conduction: continuous conduction, saltatory conduction
Synapse: structure, synaptic transmission (neurotransmitters — acetylcholine, noradrenaline)
Central nervous system (CNS): brain and spinal cord
Brain: cerebrum (cerebral cortex, motor areas, sensory areas, association areas), cerebellum, diencephalon (thalamus, hypothalamus), brain stem (midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata)
Meninges: dura mater, arachnoid, pia mater; cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Spinal cord: structure (grey matter, white matter), functions
Reflex action and reflex arc: definition, components, types (spinal, cranial)
Peripheral nervous system (PNS): somatic nervous system, autonomic nervous system (sympathetic, parasympathetic)

Sense organs — Eye: structure (cornea, iris, pupil, lens, retina — rods, cones, fovea, blind spot, optic nerve), mechanism of vision, common defects (myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism, cataract, glaucoma)

Sense organs — Ear: structure (external ear, middle ear — ossicles, Eustachian tube; inner ear — cochlea, semicircular canals, vestibular apparatus), mechanism of hearing, mechanism of balance/equilibrium
out_of_scope: Basic nervous system overview — Covered in Classes 7-10
Detailed neuroanatomy (Brodmann areas, basal ganglia, limbic system) — Undergraduate
Detailed neuropharmacology (drug actions on synapses) — Undergraduate
Detailed electrophysiology (patch clamp, EEG interpretation) — Undergraduate
Sensory physiology of taste, smell, and touch in detail — Undergraduate

concepts.concept_name: Endocrine glands: hypothalamus, pituitary, thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, pineal
Hormones of pancreas, gonads, thymus, and GI tract; mechanism of hormone action
Disorders of the endocrine system: dwarfism, gigantism, goitre, diabetes, Addison's disease

in_scope: Endocrine system: definition, endocrine glands vs exocrine glands
Hormones: chemical nature — peptide/protein hormones, steroid hormones, amino acid derivatives
Hypothalamus: releasing and inhibiting hormones, neuro-endocrine coordination
Pituitary gland (hypophysis): anterior lobe (GH, PRL, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, MSH), posterior lobe (oxytocin, ADH/vasopressin)
Pineal gland: melatonin — role in circadian rhythm
Thyroid gland: T3 and T4 (thyroxine), calcitonin — roles and regulation
Parathyroid gland: parathyroid hormone (PTH) — calcium regulation
Thymus: thymosin — role in T-cell maturation and immunity
Adrenal gland: cortex (cortisol, aldosterone, androgens) and medulla (adrenaline, noradrenaline)
Pancreas (endocrine): islets of Langerhans — insulin (beta cells), glucagon (alpha cells), somatostatin (delta cells)
Gonads: testis (testosterone), ovary (estrogen, progesterone)
Hormones of heart (ANF), kidney (erythropoietin), GI tract (gastrin, secretin, CCK, GIP)
Mechanism of hormone action: receptors — membrane-bound receptors (second messenger — cAMP) and intracellular receptors (steroid hormones, gene activation)
Feedback regulation: positive and negative feedback
Disorders: dwarfism, gigantism, acromegaly (GH), cretinism, myxoedema, goitre (thyroid), diabetes mellitus (insulin), Addison's disease, Cushing's syndrome (adrenal)
out_of_scope: Basic endocrine system overview — Covered in Classes 8-10
Detailed signal transduction cascades — Undergraduate
Detailed reproductive endocrinology — Class 12
Clinical endocrinology and hormone assays — Undergraduate / Medical
Detailed pharmacology of hormonal drugs — Undergraduate / Medical
